Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story: The line at the register snakes around the corner, and the air is thick with impatience. I force a smile as the next customer slams her items on the counter, her voice sharp and accusing about a sale price. My manager’s eyes flick over, reminding me to stay cheerful, to be the calm in the holiday storm. I nod, apologizing, my hands steady even as my heart pounds. But beneath my uniform, I’m uneasy. The office function is this afternoon, and the memo said “festive attire”—something bright, something fun. My colleagues will be there, men and women, and I know the expectation: to blend in, to look the part. But my faith asks for modesty, for sleeves that reach my wrists and a scarf that covers my hair. I can already hear the questions, the curious glances. I want to be a good coworker, a friendly face behind the register, but I also want to honor my beliefs. The weight of both roles presses on me as I ring up the last item, my mind racing with what I’ll do when my shift ends.
